question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the measure, in degrees, of the smallest positive angle $\theta$ for which $\sin 3 \theta = \cos 7 \theta.$
inference:
$$\sin 3 \theta = \cos 7 \theta$$

$$\sin 3 \theta = \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{2} - 7 \theta\right)$$

$$3 \theta = \frac{\pi}{2} - 7 \theta$$

$$10 \theta = \frac{\pi}{2}$$

$$\theta = \boxed{\frac{\pi}{20}}$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{\pi}{20}}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Note that $\cos 7 \theta = \sin (90^\circ - 7 \theta),$ so
\[\sin 3 \theta = \sin (90^\circ - 7 \theta).\]If $3 \theta = 90^\circ - 7 \theta,$ then $\theta = 9^\circ.$

If $0^\circ < \theta < 9^\circ,$ then $\sin 3 \theta < \sin 27^\circ$ and $\sin (90^\circ - 7 \theta) > \sin 27^\circ,$ so the smallest positive solution is $\boxed{9^\circ}.$
